docs.snippet: Southfork. That was the first name I had in mind way back when I was searching for space. I was surprised that no restaurant had gobbled up that easy play on words since the Hamptons are located on the South Fork of Long Island and the name lends ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Southfork. That was the first name I had in mind way back when I was searching for space. I was surprised that no restaurant had gobbled up that easy play on words since the Hamptons are located on the South Fork of Long Island and the name lends itself naturally to various logos. Southfork. Sweet and simple. Then I consulted my two newest and dearest friends, Google and Go Daddy. What's a restaurant without a discrete identity and a findable Web site? Google spit out South Forks as if it were an unhinged dishwasher. In Texas, Minnesota, Indiana, Colorado, and Long Island. From South Fork Boats in Arizona to Southfork Angus in Australia. Type in ''Southfork Restaurant'' and you get a list of restaurants on the South Fork. Of Texas, and Minnesota, and Indiana, and

headline.main: Sticking a Fork In the Name Game

docs.snippet: Marc Ambinder on his bariatric surgery....
docs.lead_paragraph: "There is a way to beat obesity. But it is radical and expensive. No other diet or weight-loss approach is remotely as effective as bariatric surgery. Most people who seek it out have tried everything else. Many of them can pinpoint the moment they concluded that they had no other choice. Mine came late in the afternoon on June 13, 2008, when I learned that Tim Russert, the Meet the Press host, had died of a sudden heart attack at NBC's Washington bureau. I didn't know Russert well, but as I sat at my desk, my tolerance for the status quo ended. I'm 30 years old, I remember thinking. I can't spend another decade like this. I Googled bariatric surgery Washington D.C. Nine months later, on a morning in March 2009, Dr. Joseph Afram, the director of the bariatric-surgery program at George Washington University Hospital, picked up his scalpel and went to work, carefully separating my stomach from my digestive pouch and leaving a walnut-size cavity, which he then attached directly to my small intestine. When he was done, my stomach was no longer."

headline.main: Metamorphosis

docs.abstract: Marc Ambinder on his bariatric surgery.

byline.original: By THE NEW Y ORK TIMES

docs.snippet: Tensions between Twitter and its developers and an interview with Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway, top this week's Tech Talk podcast....
docs.lead_paragraph: In this week's Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein finds out why Twitter app developers are worried. She speaks with Claire Cain Miller, The Times technology reporter who covers Twitter, about the company's moves toward building its own tools for the microblogging service, and the concerns among developers who fear that Twitter might turn into a competitor. Independent developers have created some 70,000 apps that let users do things like track messages on cellphones, monitor multiple Twitter accounts, shorten link addresses and post photos on the service.Dean Kamen, inventor of the Segway, is also a strong advocate of promoting science and technology education. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Mr. Kamen about his own early inspirations and about the nonprofit group he founded to encourage interest in these fields among the young. The organization, called First (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology), holds its 19th annual championship, with competitions in robotics, gaming and Lego construction, April 15-17 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta.You might expect your brand new computer to have a clean hard drive, only to find programs installed on it that you didn't ask for, or trial versions of software that pester you to buy the full version or sign up for a service. There is a name for that, as Pedro Rafael Rosado explains in his regularly featured audio essay on tech terms.Also on the show, Ms. Biersdorfer rounds up tech news of the week, including updates for the Google Docs service, a new fleet of MacBook Pro laptops from Apple; Neflix streaming movies via Wii game consoles; and prepackaged movies on portable Seagate drives. And if you can't wait for baseball season to start, her tech tip of the week can help you get set: MySportsCal lets you download your favorite team's schedule right into your Outlook, iCal or Google calendar.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Dean Kamen

docs.abstract: Tensions between Twitter and its developers and an interview with Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway, top this week's Tech Talk podcast.

docs.snippet: How this thing called 'Google' unexpectedly saved the owner's business -- and set him up for disaster....
docs.lead_paragraph: Two disadvantages of selling residential furniture are that the average sale is small and you have to work really, really hard to get it. The Partner and I both realized that it would be hard to build the business (you can see my previous posts here) selling only dining furniture. Residential clients want to sit in the chair, to feel the finish and to thump the table top before they buy. Which means we could only sell to clients who came to the shop, and that's a relatively small group.

headline.main: Staying Alive: The Wipe Out

docs.snippet: A selection of news of interest to Bay Area residents....
docs.lead_paragraph: Hackers Breached Google's Password System | Google disclosed in January that Internet intruders had stolen information from its computers. Now, a person with direct knowledge of the investigation has told John Markoff of The New York Times that the company's password system was breached. The program, known as Gaia for the Greek goddess of the earth, allows users to sign in once to operate a range of services. It was attacked last December. The hackers do not appear to have stolen Gmail users' passwords, and the company quickly beefed up security. But the theft leaves open the possibility that hackers can find other weaknesses, according to independent computer experts. [The New York Times]

headline.main: Sampler: Breach of Google Passwords, and Cash for Old Appliances

docs.snippet: On this week's Bits blog the missing iPhone consumed the discussion during the early part of the week, then commentary moved to privacy, or lack thereof, on Google and Facebook....
docs.lead_paragraph: As the week comes to a close iPhonegate continues to captivate the country; stores remain closed, truckers can't buy gasoline, life is essentially at a standstill ... O.K., it didn't really captivate the country, but the missing iPhone did make it onto almost every major media outlet, including "Good Morning America" and "Late Show With David Letterman." Still, in the nerdosphere, the debate continues among technologist and gadget blogs. But what did commenters on The Times Web site think? Many believed that the entire production was just another Apple publicity stunt.

headline.main: Comments of the Week: iPhonegate, Privacy and Facebook

docs.snippet: 2:59 p.m. | Updated  Added Blippy's explanation on its Web site of what went wrong.     In my article in Friday's New York Times, I wrote about sites that let people share all kinds of personal information with the world, and about how these sites...
docs.lead_paragraph: 2:59 p.m. | Updated Added Blippy's explanation on its Web site of what went wrong. In my article in Friday's New York Times, I wrote about sites that let people share all kinds of personal information with the world, and about how these sites are embraced by users, despite possible privacy concerns. Now the blog VentureBeat has unearthed one of those problems involving a site I wrote about, Blippy, which lets people publish their credit card purchases online.

headline.main: Privacy Watchers Criticize Google

docs.snippet: For much of this decade, the fates of Palm and Motorola were intertwined. Both were early innovators in the mobile phone industry, but neither had had a hit in years.      Motorola, which had invented cellphones and found great success with the Ra...
docs.lead_paragraph: For much of this decade, the fates of Palm and Motorola were intertwined. Both were early innovators in the mobile phone industry, but neither had had a hit in years. Motorola, which had invented cellphones and found great success with the Razr, and Palm, which pioneered the hand-held computer category, watched more nimble competitors lure away consumers with flashier, sleeker and more functional smartphones.

headline.main: How the Destinies of Motorola and Palm Grew Apart

docs.abstract: Hewlett-Packard's purchase of Palm highlights different paths that Palm and Motorola have taken after both being early innovators in mobile phone industry; Motorola was quick to adopt Google's Android software system for its devices, while Palm has chosen to go its own way with their own operating system and competing directly with Apple's iPhone; Motorola annouces unexpected profit in first quarter; says company shipped 2.3 million smartphones in quarter, numbers likely to reach 12 million to 14 million by year's end; reports net income of $69 million, compared with loss of $231 million year earlier; revenue saw smallest decline in three years, at $5 billion; photos; drawing (M)
